abstract_summ: More in-depth psychosocial research is needed using nationally representative samples that can help to inform potential mental health risks, as well as by targeting specific mental health interventions.The intent of this work was to examine the intersection of COVID-19 fear with social vulnerabilities and mental health consequences among adults living in the United States.The social and economic consequences of COVID-19 and related public health interventions aimed at slowing the spread of the virus have been proposed to increase suicide risk.This level of risk varied across social vulnerability groupings: Blacks, Native Americans, Hispanics, families with children, unmarried, and younger respondents reported higher SBQ-R scores than their counterparts (p < 0.000).This study examined the relations of two COVID-19 consequences (i.e., stay-at-home orders and job loss) to suicide risk through thwarted belongingness, perceived burdensomeness, and loneliness.
title_summ: Thwarted Belongingness and Perceived Burdensomeness Explain the Associations of COVID-19 Social and Economic Consequences to Suicide Risk.Women worry about family, men about the economy: Gender differences in emotional responses to COVID-19Unhappiness and AgeLife satisfaction among adolescents before and during the COVID-19 pandemic.Suicidality in the Middle of the COVID-19 Pandemic.Fear of COVID-19 and the mental health consequences in America.
title_abstract_phrases: More in-depth psychosocial research is needed using nationally representative samples that can help to inform potential mental health risks, as well as by targeting specific mental health interventions.The intent of this work was to examine the intersection of COVID-19 fear with social vulnerabilities and mental health consequences among adults living in the United States.OBJECTIVE The social and economic consequences of COVID-19 and related public health interventions aimed at slowing the spread of the virus have been proposed to increase suicide risk.(PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved).Women worry about family, men about the economy: Gender differences in emotional responses to COVID-19Among the critical challenges around the COVID-19 pandemic is dealing with potentially detrimental effects on people's mental health.This level of risk varied across social vulnerability groupings: Blacks, Native Americans, Hispanics, families with children, unmarried, and younger respondents reported higher SBQ-R scores than their counterparts (p < 0.000).
